detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 5: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Prosecutors have an extraordinary amount of power in the criminal-legal system, but they are subjected to almost no oversight. This combination of great power and little oversight creates a system that tramples on the rights of people charged with crimes. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Given their broad discretion over which cases are charged, whether cases proceed to trial, and the sentences individuals receive, prosecutors exert enormous influence over who is subjected to the brutality of the criminal-legal system and for how long. Like the rest of the criminal-legal system, this discretion is infected with racial bias, which influences every step of the process. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Because of high rates of pretrial detention and mandatory minimum sentences, prosecutors have power to coerce plea agreements: People who are detained, facing financial hardship, and desperate to go home are more likely to plead guilty than take their case to trial, even if they’re legally innocent. Research shows that people detained before trial plead to more severe penalties than people charged with the same crimes but who aren’t detained. The vast majority of cases — 97 percent of federal cases and 94 percent of state cases — end in plea agreements.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Even when prosecutors intentionally break the rules, such as by not fulfilling their constitutional mandate to produce exculpatory “Brady” evidence that favors those accused of a crime or impeaches a government witness, the court-created doctrine of “absolute immunity” protects prosecutors from facing liability.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a system where prosecutors are accountable to the people and communities who are subject to the devastating toll of criminal prosecution. Our laws and policies must be changed to ensure sufficient transparency and accountability regarding prosecutorial decisions and prosecutorial misconduct. Above all, we must begin rebalancing our resources so that we invest in upfront, non-carceral services that address social problems wholly outside of the criminal-legal process. Only then will we be able to reduce the devastating effects of prosecutors with too much power and too little accountability.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Abolish the “trial penalty” by passing legislation that codifies and strengthens judicial discretion and oversight in reviewing plea agreements.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End federal and state civil immunities for prosecutors.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a system where people returning from prison have access to non-punitive, community-based supports.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Protect communities with a new paradigm for public safety beyond policing

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A new paradigm for public safety emphasizes non-carceral interventions and programs, not jails and prisons, to keep communities safe. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}
